Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

content:
The screenshot you posted shows a combination of two issues going on there.

One is you're using Cards View, which doesn't allow you to choose the information that Thunderbird displays there. You'd have to use Table View if you want to be able to choose the information you want to be displayed in the message list: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova

The other issue is that you appear to not have configured that account properly to make Thunderbird use the right folder for saving sent messages, so Thunderbird is treating that folder as any other folder, not as a special Sent folder. Go to Account Settings > Copies & Folders, select Other for saving sent messages and choose the Sent Mail folder from the list of available options there. That will make Thunderbird change the information it displays in Cards View for that folder.
creator: DavidGG

content:
I don't know why the server doesn't accept those attachments, but the attachment the server is complaining about is the very message you're trying to forward because you're forwarding the message as an attachment. It doesn't matter whether the forwarded message has attachments of its own or not.

The default forwarding mode can be changed in Settings > Composition. You may choose there to forward messages Inline instead of as attachments. You can also choose how you want to forward a particular message regardless of the default setting by right clicking on the message you want to forward and choosing Forward As.
creator: DavidGG

content:
If automatic account configuration doesn't work, you have to choose Configure manually. You'll need to know what your account settings should be and manually configure the account according to those settings.

In principle, Spectrum publishes the settings needed to configure the mail client here: https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/spectrum-email-server-settings

The quality of both their "tech support" and of the info provided there leaves a lot to be desired, though. In particular, the incoming and the outgoing servers seem to require different security settings (SSL/TLS for the incoming server, STARTTLS for the outgoing server), something that's not stated anywhere in that page and that their own "tech support" doesn't seem to know either, but you may see in this other page, which may or may not use the right server names for your email address, but the rest of settings shown there probably do apply to you:

https://www.postbox-inc.com/setup/email-settings/access-rr-com-via-imap-smtp
creator: DavidGG

I have nothing but praise for Spectrum CS, like Time Warner before them. I have no way of knowing how much they actually know, but they have always been extremely interested in CS and have always solved my problems. This one may have been out of their wheelhouse. Nobody knows everything, eh?

They did offer one tip that was crucial. In case this conversation is archived/searchable somewhere, that one tip is that the Host Server for incoming/outgoing mail has to be "mail.twc.com."

DavidGG - Your tip on the Outgoing Server Security made the difference. My new Thunderbird email is up and running. Thank you VERY much! I hope it is as trouble free as the old MS Mail program I used for years up until MS forced everyone into Outlook. It's entirely possible that this same setup tip would make it work too.

content: What you're observing is a combination of POP being the wrong mail protocol for what you want to do and Gmail being a very particular email provider with a lot of idiosyncrasies. Set up your Gmail account as IMAP instead.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Hi David, Thanks for coming back to me.

Yes, probably right, the reason I used POP was that I read somewhere that IMAP for Gmail doesn't keep your emails and I wanted to be able to access all my historical emails - probably wrong but that's what I understood....

If I change (if I can) my Gmail and Thunderbird settings to IMAP what will happen? - will it download _all_ my email again? (I'd prefer that to losing them!) or will it just be an empty message new slate? I'm nervous of doing anything that means I'll lose stuff....

Also, to help me with what I've got currently, can you advise if there's anything I can do to make the current POP Inbox folders show their messages?

Sorry it's complicated....what I really want is a magic wand :)
creator: Nears

content:
You cannot change the type of an account you have already set up. You have to set up the account anew. But you don't have to remove from Thunderbird the POP account you already have if you don't want to, you may set it up as IMAP and keep both setups for a while if you want until you get used to IMAP.

The IMAP account will show in Thunderbird what's on the server for the folders you subscribe to. I'd recommend not subscribing to All Mail, but Thunderbird will definitely try to show all the mail you have in Inbox on the server. And if you remove a message from Inbox in Thunderbird using the IMAP account, it will be removed from Inbox on the server too.

Not sure how to fix your Inbox problems because I don't even understand what you say about getting a "Couldn't load XPCOM" error message, doesn't make sense to me, but don't create subfolders of Inbox to organise your mail locally on your computer. Use Local Folders at the bottom of the folder pane for that.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Not sure what you mean. The message is automatically moved to Trash if you read it, but is left in Inbox if you don't?

what is the difference between the trash folder and the deleted folder in the Thunderbird app?

Trash is the folder Thunderbird would try to use by default and may create if not present. The other folder may be the default folder created for the same purpose by the mail server. You may tell Thunderbird to use one or the other in Account Settings > Server Settings > When I delete a message.
